title: What's News: Business & Finance
text:
Toyota Motor stepped up its commitment to electric vehicles, saying the company would make 3.5 million EVs a year by 2030.

Chinese authorities said they have fined social-media giant Weibo millions of dollars for a string of infractions.

U.S. stocks ended lower as the Fed kicked off its policy meeting. The S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq lost 0.7%, 0.3% and 1.1%, respectively.

Biden plans to nominate Sandra Thompson to become the permanent director of the agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

Israeli cybersecurity company NSO Group is exploring a potential sale of its business or the closure of its controversial spyware unit.

3M agreed to combine its food-safety business with Neogen, a food testing and animal healthcare specialist.

Chanel named Unilever executive Leena Nair to become its chief executive, reaching outside the fashion market.

Apple stores across the U.S. are returning to requiring masks as Covid-19 cases rise.

What's News: Business & Finance
